contentrichtext.text: [[Image:Provinces of Japan-Bungo.svg|thumb|right|Map of Japanese provinces (1868) with Bungo Province highlighted]] ''This article is about the historical province of Japan. For Bungo the Womble, see [[The Wombles]].'' {{nihongo|'''Bungo Province'''|豊後国|Bungo no kuni}} was a [[Provinces of Japan|province]] of [[Japan]] in eastern [[Kyūshū]] in the area of [[Ōita Prefecture]].<ref>[[Louis-Frédéric|Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric]]. (2005). "''Bungo''" in {{Google books|p2QnPijAEmEC|''Japan Encyclopedia'', p. 90|page=90}}.</ref> It was sometimes called {{nihongo|'''Hōshū'''|豊州}}, with [[Buzen Province]]. Bungo bordered [[Buzen Province|Buzen]], [[Hyūga Province|Hyūga]], [[Higo Province|Higo]], [[Chikugo Province|Chikugo]], and [[Chikuzen Province|Chikuzen]] Provinces. ==History== At the end of 7th century, [[Toyo Province]] was split into ''Buzen'' (literally, "the front of ''Toyo''") and ''Bungo'' ("the back of ''Toyo''"). Until the [[Heian period]], Bungo was read as ''Toyokuni no Michi no Shiri''. It is believed that the capital of Bungo was located in the ''Kokokufu'' (古国府), literally "old capital," section of the city of [[Ōita, Ōita|Ōita]] but to this day, no remains have been found. The honor of the holiest [[Shinto]] shrine of Bungo province (豊前一宮, ''Buzen ichinomiya'') was given to [[Usa Shrine]] known as Usa Hachimangu or Usa Jingu in Usa district (today [[Usa, Ōita]]). Usa shrine had not only religious authority but also political influence to local governance, but their influence was reduced until the Sengoku period. During the [[Sengoku Period]], in the middle of 16th century, Bungo was a stronghold of the [[Ōtomo clan]]. The [[Ōuchi clan]] in the western [[Chūgoku Region]] was influenced to Buzen politics. In the middle of the period, both clans declined. After [[Toyotomi Hideyoshi]] also took the power in Kyūshū, 120 thousand [[koku]] of Buzen province was given to [[Kuroda Yoshitaka]] since 1587, who made [[Kokura]], currently part of [[Kitakyushu, Fukuoka]], his site and built the castle. Other parts of the province were divided into pieces and given to other [[daimyo]]. In the [[Meiji period]], the provinces of Japan were converted into prefectures. Maps of Japan and Bungo Province were [[reform]]ed in the 1870s.<ref>Nussbaum, [http://books.google.com/books?id=p2QnPijAEmEC&pg=PA780&dq= "Provinces and prefectures"] at p. 780.</ref> ==Shrines and temples== [[File:YusuharaHachimangu Shaden.JPG|thumb|right|''Yusuhara-hachiman-gū'']] ''[[Sasamuta-jinja]]'' and ''[[Yusuhara Hachiman-gū]]'' were the chief [[Shinto shrine]]s (''[[ichinomiya]]'') of Bungo.<ref>[http://eos.kokugakuin.ac.jp/modules/xwords/images/uploads/EOS070712Ab.pdf "Nationwide List of ''Ichinomiya''," p. 3]; retrieved 2012-1-18.</ref> ==Former Districts== *[[Hita District, Ōita|Hita District]] (日高郡) *[[Kusu District, Ōita|Kusu District]] (球珠郡) *[[Naoiri District, Ōita|Naoiri District]] (直入郡) *[[Ōno District, Ōita|Ōno District]] (大野郡) *Amabe District (海部郡) *[[Ōita District, Ōita|Ōita District]] (大分郡) *[[Hayami District, Ōita|Hayami District]] (速見郡) *Kunisaki District (国埼郡) ==See also== * [[Kitsuki Domain]] * [[Mori Domain (Bungo)|Mori Domain]] * [[Funai Domain]] ==Notes== {{reflist}} == External links == {{Commons category-inline|Bungo Province}} * [http://www.maproom.org/00/05/sub1/1.html Murdoch's map of provinces, 1903] {{Japan Old Province}} [[Category:Former provinces of Japan]]
